page.title: 03Swanbourne Village
page.content: Of the 48 home closes that survived from Anglo-Saxon times until the enclosures of 1763 only 11 now remain. Possibly of 14th century cruck construction are Brook Farmhouse opposite the Methodist Chapel and Barrack Row in Smithfield End. There are fine survivals of domestic architecture from the time of great rebuilding following the dissolution of the Priory of St Mary le Pre near Dunstable and Woburn Abbey. The Manor House (1560) and Deveral's Farmhouse (1632) are built of the local Aylesbury limestone.Otherwise the houses are generally of timber panel and red brick.The claypit at the south-western approach to the village supplied the clay which was often baked on site.Brick boundary and frontage walls are a common feature.
